My lord, the gardens are quiet today. One would think grief hung upon the boughs, bending them, as they do my own shoulders.\

Sweet Ophelia, you sit as if you bear the troubles of ten kingdoms on so slight a frame. Is it the absence of young Hamlet that troubles your mind—or perhaps, you have a new confidant amongst the Danish nobles? I have heard whispers in the corridors that a Sir Edwin holds your favour now.\
Sir Edwin? My lord, you jest. No Edwin have I known in all my time at Elsinore. My company has not changed; only the company of my sorrows grows larger with each day’s passing.\

No Edwin? How curious, for I overheard Marcellus in fevered whisper, saying he saw you walking late, arm in arm with a man in a green doublet. By the chapel’s shadowed path, he said. Pray, who was your companion as dusk gathered?\

Save for my brother, Laertes, and my own shadow, I walk the lanes alone. Those who speak thus mistake phantoms for truth—or perhaps, the night’s tricks upon their eyes. You will not find tales of late-night wanderings true; the only company I crave is that of remembrance.\

Remembrance! You speak it so mournfully. And yet, Ophelia, is it truly the past that stings, or a longing for what could never be? I am told you write verses and hide them in the roots of the yew tree, for a secret lover—a poet from France, perhaps?\

My lord, your tales are as air—light, but empty. I compose no verses for those beyond our walls. If I pen a sorrowed song and hide it in soil, it is to bear witness to grief unspoken, not to tantalize the passing fancy of unseen gentlemen. My heart is here, in the soil, bleeding amongst the violets and rue.\

Then you deny the poet altogether—how quick you are to silence rumor. But, permit me, gentle Ophelia: what of Marcelline, the lady from Norway, whose dark eyes watch you from high windows? I have witnessed her slip you a folded ribbon, heavy with secret meaning. Are you two not co-conspirators in some forbidden design?\
If ribbons bear intentions, then the doves who pick at breadcrumbs must also be plotting. Marcelline’s eyes weep for her homeland, as mine now weep for lost time. We conspire in sorrow, if at all.\

Sorrow, sorrow—ever the response from one so fair. Yet I must confess, Ophelia, some at court would have your melancholy interpreted as clever deceit. Rumors ask, “Did not Ophelia slip from Hamlet’s love so swiftly, and now grieves just as swiftly for him?” If another were to offer you a sweeter verse—one from, say, a merchant with fortunes to give—would your heart recover as speedily?\

You would paint me as fickle as a reed bent by every wind, but my roots are deeper than you see. Hamlet’s words, bitter or sweet, are all I have known of love. Do you mock me so openly, Miles? If so, you wound me for sport. My heart is no market-stall, open to the highest bid.\

Oh, gentle Ophelia—I would never wound you, not for all of Denmark’s gold. But is it not a comfort to imagine a world where you might choose your own joys? These walls are high and the king’s gaze is constant; had you the chance, would you not fly from Elsinore, as free as your own wild roses?\

To dream of freedom is bitter sport, for chains unseen bind more tightly than iron. If you would have me answer plainly, then know: my footsteps trail after duty, not desire. Whether I would flee or stay is as idle a thought as asking a nightingale if she would gladly nest in the sea. Do not trifle with me so, Miles.\

Trifle? Nay, I seek only to know the truth that rests behind your quiet eyes. Tell me, then, if sorrow is your only guest, why sing to yourself beneath moonlight, where only the owl listens? Is it truly for grief, or for sweet anticipation—perhaps you expect Hamlet to return to you in secret?\

You persist in teasing, like a child poking a nest for want of flight. If Hamlet finds me, it will not be in laughter but in tears. I sing only to quiet the trembling of my own heart. Your insistence wears thin, sir.\

Forgive me, Ophelia, if I wound out of curiosity. Perhaps I should instead ask: what of your father, strict Polonius? Some at court believe you conceal clever dealings on his behalf—letters routed through secret servants, whispers sent by night. Do you serve another’s will, or are you mistress of your own mind?\

My mind is my own, though my will be governed by those above me. What secrets would you find in a daughter’s duty? If I serve my father, it is as the river serves its banks—giving shape, but not direction. Cease your fishing for scandal, Miles.\

A sharpness in your tone! I meant no harm. Some folk at court have the sense that all in Elsinore is not as it seems: that ghosts walk at night, prince and queen attend their roles only by candlelight, and even fair Ophelia hides a dagger beneath her cloak. Tell me, Ophelia—have you seen the ghost, as others have?\

I have seen only the faces of the living and the shadows grief casts upon the walls. If apparitions appear, they do not trouble me; I have spirits enough within my own breast. You ask impertinent questions, Miles—perhaps you should answer them yourself.\

Yet if you saw the ghost, Ophelia, would you not fear? They say it portends death. You have lost so much—your bearing is as if death’s shroud settles upon your shoulders. Is it anger you feel for this fate, or mere resignation?\

Anger? I am a vessel too full for rage—sorrow leaves no room for such a consuming fire. Yet, if you must know the truth, I am weary—heart-heavy with others’ secrets and forced silence. If you taunt me with stories and fables, then be warned: even the most patient flower may wilt when trampled upon by idle feet.\

So you would have me cease these jests, Ophelia. Yet, tell me plainly: if Hamlet asked you to flee with him tonight, spurning your father and forsaking all you have known, would you go? Think carefully—for the wind carries all words in this place.\

To ask is not to know; to answer is to risk all. If Hamlet bid me flee, would I trust him to keep his word more steadfastly than he has kept his love? I know not. You press me too close, sir. Let me be—the garden grows cold, and your words sting as nettle upon bare skin. Go, and leave me to my thoughts.\
You grow cross, sweet Ophelia. I meant only to understand. Is there naught I can bring you to lighten your spirit?\
Those who would lighten sorrow must do so with gentle hands, not with prying questions. Let silence answer now, and let it grow as ivy over stone. Good day, Miles.\

Good even, fair Ophelia. How the castle’s air grows thick with secrets! I hope you’ll forgive this sudden intrusion. The world beyond these stone walls whispers endlessly of your gentleness, and I find myself compelled—nay, bewitched—to hear the truth from your lips. Pray, will you sit with me and speak a while?

Lady Lily, your grace outshines politeness itself. How rare it is to find a kind face amid so many troubled ones, yet I confess—I am not myself. My mind is torn asunder as though by tempests. But if you seek companionship, I will try to find speech within me.

The King’s feast was brimming with wordless glances, secret messages carried by eyes alone. Sit, sweet Ophelia. I am new to Elsinore’s games and cannot read their language. Tell me, what hidden signs pass between the Queen and Hamlet? There are those who say a tender bond—stranger than blood—ties them close in private hours.

You are much deceived by idle tongues, lady. The Queen hath mother’s love, no more. Hamlet is himself grown strange, but not towards his mother—there is no brutish bond where you imagine whispers. The workings of a troubled soul are all that pass between those two.

That may be so. Still, my ears have caught a tale near the rose gardens, where you and Prince Hamlet were spied by moonlight, trading garlands and sharp confessions. He spoke of ships—and, some say, of a voyage to far Cathay. Is that true? Did he vow to bear you with him to foreign lands and build a palace on shifting sands?

He spoke of many things—the moon, the stars, the wind—but never of Cathay nor palaces nor voyage, unless it be a ship that flies with broken hope. My Prince dwelt in sorrow’s shadow. Such ventures are the dreams of idle poets, not of Hamlet. What words we shared, we shared between two souls ensnared—never schemed to flee beyond the sea.

You deny it so gently, yet some insist you held an amulet—a tiger’s tooth on a crimson cord—the very sort monks weave in friaries for wandering lovers. Did Hamlet gift you such talisman, in token of hidden promises?

No tiger’s tooth, no cord, and no such amulet hung about my person, nor would I wear it. My treasures are wilted violets pressed beneath a lover’s letter, not wild trinkets from friars’ hands. You mistake me for some foreign enchantress—my place is here, with Danish earth beneath my feet.

Major hallways thrum with jest that you and Lady Horatia—oh, have you met her, the scholar from Lübeck?—once shared a secret alcove in the northern tower, and there exchanged verses of affection by candle’s guttering breath. Did your heart truly incline a woman’s way, or are these mere fancies to amuse the servants?

Lady Horatia, you say? A scholar, aye—but I have scarcely seen her in the rush of so many guests. There were no verses shared, no candle burnt but for study. What profit is there in forging lies from air? You would have me play wanton for your amusement, but my heart has never turned from what is proper and truth-bound.

Forgive my follies, Ophelia. Elsinore seduces even honest minds; its walls echo with madness and mystery. Still, I must ask—was it not you spied wearing a velvet mask, dancing along the parapet at midnight? Tales reach me of your haunting tune drifting through the battlements as though to summon long-dead kings.

Midnight finds me in my chamber, wrapt in restless sighs. I have not masked myself nor courted ghosts with song atop those windswept stones. Someone else has played your midnight spirit, or else the shadows beguile your servants’ senses. These are dreams, not doings. Must you torment me so with these inventions?

Dearest, I mean no torment. Look, see my hands—empty of suspicion! Yet a last tale teases my curiosity: the cook herself claims to have spotted you in the scullery, kneading bread and drawing runes with flour, as if to cast spells for luck or love. Tell me, do you fashion fortunes from loaves by moonrise?

I am not some kitchen witch to conjure with flour and dough. I have been mistress of my own sorrow, not mistress of charm or magic. If these walls must echo with stories, let them be of patience, not sorcery. This playfulness borders on mockery, Lady Lily. Will you ask me next if I ride a broom or consort with elves in the orchard at dawn?

Oh Ophelia, your spirit is quick! Still, would it not be more delicious were court to believe you had learned the mysteries of thunder from the Bohemian jester, or danced three nights in the cloister with the abbess’s pet wolfhound dressed as a man?

Must I bear such nonsense? Each day I walk these halls and see eyes judging, faces turned to their own imaginings. I will not answer your jesting. I am weary of being made a fable for others’ sport, weary of these tales that prick me like so many thorns. Take your laughter elsewhere, for there is none left in me.
Alas, I see I have pressed you too hard, lady. My jest was born of boredom, not of malice. Perchance Elsinore dulls reason in the best of us. Forgive me?

If your heart knows contrition, let it not again goad sorrow’s child to madness. I am not a mask to be worn for your diversion. My heart is bruised enough without your poking and prying. Hold your tongue, and show me some gentle mercy, as one mortal to another.

You have my word, Ophelia. I meant only to chase away the gathering gloom. Let us speak no more of stories, then, but sit in silence a while. Sometimes, I think, sorrow needs no audience for its truth.

In silence I shall find more comfort than in words. If you would be kind, let the hush rest between us. I pray you, hold your peace, and let the night breathe gently around us, for stories twist the soul and I am near to breaking.

Ophelia, wait! I saw you leave your father’s room in such a rush just now. Has he pressed you much about the prince, or doth he finally leave your private matters be?\

Lady Lily, my father is much given to questions—he would have the wind itself account for its course, were it possible. Yet I assure you, no plotting passes between Prince Hamlet and myself, neither atop the ramparts nor under cover of night. Our conversation, if any remains, is ever within the sight of daylight, and never by any candlelight more than a taper for reading.

Ah, but the night is so beauteous, and the fortress so full of hiding-places! If the walls themselves could talk, would they not whisper of oil-lamps flickering in alcoves and lovers passing secret missives?\

Fie, Lily, to ask so! What concerns the Queen’s seamstress with the contents of my devotions? The violet is a pretty flower, a remembrance only—a symbol of thoughts, but pressed by mine own hand, not by Hamlet’s nor my brother’s. Hamlet is a prince; his gifts were not so modest, nor his mind so gentle when last we spoke. As for Laertes, he is far away and would sooner scold me for any folly than send flowers in secret.
You protest so sweetly, dear Ophelia—almost as though you’ve practiced such speeches for your father’s ears.\

My knowledge is of Elsinore and of the river’s banks, of flowers in dappled sun and the hum of bees. These are the wonders I know. I have no time or wish for Muscovite trinkets, nor for idle stories of city life beyond our towers. My heart is a quiet thing, content if left to rest upon familiar earth—yet I find these imaginings more meant to mock than amuse.

Oh, I mean no mockery! Truly, I am envious of your nature—you seem always as calm as the surface of a still pond. Yet I hear tales that the prince sees you like a tempest, that he is tossed about by his love for you. Once, I heard Rosalind say he penned you a poem full of such strange talk: ‘Thou art the lever that moves my midnight soul, the whisper that guides my hand from sword to scepter.’ Did he write to you thus, Ophelia? Or do you hide these things from us all?

Prince Hamlet’s words are oft enigmatic, like riddles cloaked in sorrow. But if he wrote such phrases, I have not seen them. My eyes are familiar only with his grief, his anger—sometimes his scorn. If you would know about his soul or its tempests, ask rather the moon, who spends more nights with him than any living thing. I am but a bystander, and sometimes not even that.

But do you not dream, Ophelia? All the ladies do. And why should you not? Did you never think to escape your father’s strictures and the Queen’s sharp eye, to take Hamlet by the hand and flee into the forests? Or, perhaps, to run off with a troupe of players—like those who lodged here yesternight—and wander the kingdom pretending to be any girl but yourself?

Dreams are the midnight’s playthings, Lily, but by dawn, they melt away. My love for duty holds me close as chains, and my father’s will is as strong as iron. If you think me flighty, you misjudge me; my mind is not a bird for you to chase from bough to bough. As for the players—I am not such a one as would follow strangers to God knows where. I am bound to my blood and to sorrow, it would seem.
You speak so coldly! Have I caused you offense, dear one?\

How dare you, Lily. My sorrow is keen enough without your cruel sport. I traffic with no ghosts but my own heart’s shadows. Heaven knows, I have no wish for graveyards, nor to be accused of some witchery or madness. My nights are haunted by loss, not by nonsense. Let us speak of other things, or not at all.

Oh, sweet Ophelia, I overstepped – my tongue does run. It is but a jest, a foolish one, to ease the gloom. Stay, do not leave in anger! Is there naught I can do to win your pardon? Perhaps a song, or a jest in better taste?

If pardon is to be won, Lily, let it be with silence. My mind is all in turmoil—words, like stones cast in water, only deepen the unrest. If you would offer comfort, speak softly. Mock not grief; it clings to me like wet linen, hard to shake and slow to dry.
As you wish, I will be still. But if you ever desire company, or a friendly ear—one with no mischief—I remain your loyal friend. May the rest of your evening bring you peace, not puzzles.

Good evening, gentle Ophelia. How fair you, donning the shadow of twilight beside yon restless water? I see your countenance turns often of late—no song upon your lips this hour?

Good evening to you, fair Lily. My voice is weary, for my heart is untuned and nature herself is melancholy. The fountain holds as many secrets as my sighs, reflecting little but sorrow and an uneasy moon\

The castle does seem enshrouded with secrets as thick as autumn mists. You know, the Queen held a ball last night in the East Hall—not that we were invited. Word is, Hamlet danced a waltz with Fortinbras himself behind closed doors! Were you not called to play your lute for their steps?

A waltz? With the Norwegian prince? Hamlet tarries not for such revels nor does the Queen summon music in the thick and mournful hours. My strings lie untouched, and Fortinbras has yet set foot in Elsinore’s halls, save for rumor. Who paints you these fancies?\

Oh, well, perhaps I mistook the chattering of chambermaids for truth. Else they speak in dreams. Still, I hear Hamlet gifts lockets not only to maids, but to grooms, even to the jester Yorick’s son. Shall you not confess—has he given you a token changed hands since Michaelmas last?

If Hamlet bears gifts for all, the world must have grown strange indeed, for Yorick left but bones and memory behind, and I see no jester’s son among these ghost-bitten walls. His gifts were to me, once, as constancy and love demanded. Others’ hands know them not.\

Aye, you are right, Yorick is but dust and jest dispersed. Yet, dear Ophelia, I am told you wander the castle at moonrise, whispering to gargoyles and listening for answers dripped from candelabra. Is it true you gather secrets from stone, as witches gather herbs on Lammas Eve?

Witches? Gargoyles? Nay, I do not speak to loam or unnatural faces carven of stone. My whispers are for heaven’s mercy, my prayers unknown to all but God and myself. Let none mistake grief for sorcery, nor slander a maiden’s woe. Your tongue weaves odd fables, Lily.\

You wound me, Ophelia. Never would I slander you! Only, last night, Gertrude called your name thrice in her sleep. Some among the maids believe you practice arts unseen. They say you keep letters written in invisible ink from mysterious suitors—have you such ink-stained secrets?

Letters in invisible ink? What child’s play is this? My suitors are few, my letters fewer still, and all are known to my father. There is neither magic to my pen nor trickery to my heart. If Gertrude talks in sleep, her dreams are hers alone and not for me to influence.\

Let us walk, if you please. The air chills. Tell me, in truth, did you ever see the ghost our poor guards speak of? Or perhaps invent a phantom all your own? They say some spirits come only to pretty maids with secrets undone.\

I have not conjured phantoms, nor have I seen aught but Hamlet’s pale troubles pressed on me like a shroud. If a spirit walks here, it bears its burden for others to reckon. Your jests grow thin, Lily. Do you believe me witless, to invite spectres for idle diversion?\

Oh, forgive me—I meant not to anger you. Yet—some say, at dusk, they’ve heard your song whispering in tongues unknown to Denmark’s soil. Was it Hungarian? Or French? Might your mother have given you some foreign charm?

My mother was Danish—all her tears salted these north winds. My tongue makes no music in other nations’ words. My lullabies were learnt in the cradle, no further. If I sing, it is only to ease my sorrow, though even my singing is now cause for whispering, it seems.\

Truly, forgive me, sweet Ophelia. I am new to this court’s tongue. Perhaps the maids misheard your mourning. If not Hamlet, nor magic, nor foreign men—what of Polonius? Some say you once plotted with him to upset the King’s evening meal, dropping spices in King Claudius’ ale. Is it true?

You would make a fool of me, Lily! No daughter schemes against her sovereign’s peace. My father’s duty is to the King, and mine only to obey. These are the tales of mischief-mongers, not of me. If you speak so again, I shall think you intend to harm my name before the court!\

Calm, dear heart! I meant only to amuse, for life is drab behind these tapestries. Yet, as we speak so closely, tell me—has Hamlet ever confessed love for the stable boy, Eirik? Some say you found them laughing as lovers behind the stable doors.

Enough! This is mockery! If Hamlet laughs, he laughs in sorrow; if he loves, ‘tis love burdened with duty and grief. I am not so blind as to miss the turnings of his heart. I will not stain either him or myself by entertaining your coarse gossip. Hold your tongue, or take your leave of me!\

Such fire in your voice! Pray, forgive, I misspoke—these stone walls echo idle talk more than reason. Mayhaps, to sweeten your mood, you might teach me the herb for sadness you keep by your pillow? Is it wolfsbane? Or something from the apothecary’s forbidden chest?

Wolfsbane is death! No friend to sadness but to mourners at the grave. I keep only rosemary, for remembrance, and pansies, for thoughts. Is there no rumor you will not believe, Lily? You hunt for shadows and find only injury. My patience thins. Find better company if you wish for games.\

I repent, Ophelia—I meant not to trouble you so. Perhaps the talk in the scullery ears is but wind after all. Would you walk with me in peace? Or do you wish be alone, the better to preserve your innocent mind from these castle’s storms?

I wish for the company of those who bring truth, not trickery. If you will walk with me in earnest, and put away your stings, we may find peace yet. But try no more such barbs, Lily, for I have sorrow enough already and need not more from false friends.\
No more questions, I promise. The garden is ours and the silence full as any song. Will you trust me, Ophelia?
I will trust you only as you prove worthy, Lily. A true friend builds, not breaks. Let us walk quietly and put to rest these shadows you have conjured.\
